dt: {bc}the gaseous products of burning materials especially of organic origin made visible by the presence of small particles of carbon
{bc}a suspension of particles in a gas
{bc}fume or vapor often resulting from the action of heat on moisture
{bc}something of little substance, permanence, or value

dt.t: if a guy's going to hit you … he certainly isn't going to throw a spitter—he gives you {wi}smoke{/wi}

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}smoca{/it}; akin to Old English {it}smēocan{/it} to emit smoke, Middle High German {it}smouch{/it} smoke, and probably to Greek {it}smychein{/it} to smolder
shortdef: the gaseous products of burning materials especially of organic origin made visible by the presence of small particles of carbon
a suspension of particles in a gas
a mass or column of smoke

dt: {bc}to inhale and exhale the fumes of burning plant material and especially tobacco
{bc}to drive (something, such as mosquitoes) away by smoke
{bc}to cure or flavor by exposure to smoke

dt.t: … offers, among other things, a flavorful sirloin steak and barbecued {wi}smoked{/wi} chicken.

dt: {bc}to stupefy (insects, such as bees) by smoke
{bc}to inhale and exhale the smoke of
{bc}to hit (something, such as a baseball) with great force
{bc}something intended to disguise or draw attention away from an often embarrassing or unpleasant issue

shortdef: something intended to disguise or draw attention away from an often embarrassing or unpleasant issue —usually hyphenated when used attributively

dt: {bc}an alarm that activates automatically when it detects smoke

shortdef: an alarm that activates automatically when it detects smoke —called also smoke alarm

dt: {bc}a room (as in a hotel) in which a small group of politicians carry on negotiations

shortdef: a room (as in a hotel) in which a small group of politicians carry on negotiations

dt: {bc}a forest firefighter who parachutes to locations otherwise difficult to reach

shortdef: a forest firefighter who parachutes to locations otherwise difficult to reach

dt: {bc}to drive out by or as if by smoke

shortdef: to drive out by or as if by smoke
to cause to be made public

dt: {bc}the temperature at which an oil or fat (especially one used for cooking) begins to emit smoke

dt.t: When choosing an oil, you want one with a higher {wi}smoke point{/wi} than your cooking temperature … since surpassing the {wi}smoke point{/wi} "can cause undesirable burnt aroma and flavors," says [Jason] Ginsberg, in addition to filling your kitchen with smoke.
Cold-pressed oils have a {wi}smoking point{/wi} of less than 300° F and should not be used for high-heat cooking.
Film the pan with peanut oil or canola oil (which have higher {wi}smoke points{/wi} than other vegetable oils).

shortdef: the temperature at which an oil or fat (especially one used for cooking) begins to emit smoke

dt: {bc}a screen of smoke to hinder enemy observation of a military force, area, or activity
{bc}something designed to obscure, confuse, or mislead

shortdef: a screen of smoke to hinder enemy observation of a military force, area, or activity
something designed to obscure, confuse, or mislead

dt: {bc}either of two small shrubby trees (genus {it}Cotinus{/it}) of the cashew family with large panicles of minute flowers that suggest a cloud of smoke:
{bc}one ({it}C. coggygria{/it}) of Eurasia that is widely planted in the eastern U.S.
{bc}one ({it}C. obovatus{/it}) of the southeastern U.S. and Texas

shortdef: either of two small shrubby trees (genus Cotinus) of the cashew family with large panicles of minute flowers that suggest a cloud of smoke:
one (C. coggygria) of Eurasia that is widely planted in the eastern U.S.
one (C. obovatus) of the southeastern U.S. and Texas
